Using a model that simulates ocean circulation, scientists studying pollution-induced warming of the globe have calculated changes in sea level by region. Their findings may be good news for penguins, but not for people.

Assuming a rise of 6 degrees Fahrenheit caused by a doubling of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, the scientists project an average worldwide sea-level rise of about 7 inches in 50 years. The North Atlantic is expected to rise about 16 inches while the Ross Sea in the Antarctic is expected to fall.
The study, conducted by Uwe Mikolajewicz and colleagues at the Max Planck Meteorology Institute in Hamburg, West Germany, appears in the current issue of the journal Nature.

Michael E. Schlesinger, a professor of atmospheric science at the University of Illinois, who has studied atmospheric models, said this is the first published study using a model of ocean currents, which until now have been an overlooked factor in sea level change.
Dr. Mikolajewicz stressed that the study had shortcomings and its results should not be interpreted as a prediction.
